Introduction
 
The Yuma Desalting Plant uses chlorine and ammonia as a necessary part of the water treatment process.   Storing a large quantity of chlorine and ammonia can be a hazard if it is not handled properly.  The Yuma Desalting Plant is owned and operated by the Bureau of Reclamation.  As such, it takes its safety obligations in storing and using chlorine and ammonia seriously.  The following document describes what could happen if there were to be an accident, the steps the Bureau of Reclamation takes every day to ensure a safely operating plant, and what to do in the event of an emergency.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The Yuma Desalting Plant accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates proven technology, staff training on operation and maintenance practices, and tested management system practices.  All applicable procedures of the State of Arizona and U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Prevention Program are adhered to, including key elements such as training, systems management, and emergency response procedures.  

The Bureau of Reclamation recognizes the responsibility to make its environment, community and employee safety a primary part of our daily concerns.  The Bureau of Reclamation is committed to being a responsible member of any community in which it has operations by giving top priority to operating in a safe and environmentally sound manner.  The Bureau of Reclamation is dedicated to developing an environmentally responsible energy resource compatible with community needs.   The prevention of accidents and protection of its employees, property and the general public are essential to the efficient and successful completion of every project undertaken by the Bureau of Reclamation. The Bureau of Reclamation requires active injury and illness prevention as an important element of production on a daily basis.

This document complies with the EPA Risk Management Program u

nder Section 112 (r) of the Clean Air Act (CAA) Amendments of 1990, 40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Part 68.  This document summarizes the Bureau of ReclamationA?s existing health and safety programs, its internal management response procedures, and ongoing actions that are designed to prevent or minimize impacts of accidental releases of chlorine and ammonia to the environment. The Yuma Desalting Plant Authority has prepared an emergency action plan to handle any potential accidental releases.

Facility Description and Regulated Substances Information

The Yuma Desalting Plant is located at 7301 Calle Agua Salada, Yuma, Arizona in the southwest corner of Arizona near the California and Mexico borders.  The YDP is located in the northwest quarter of Yuma, immediately south of Cocopah R.V. and Golf Resort and adjacent to the Arizona Public Service Yucca Power Plant.

YDP use the chlorine to provide a chlorine solution as a disinfecting agent.  This disinfecting step is necessary to promote the destruction of algae, bacteria, micro-organisms. YDP uses the anhydrous ammonia system to convert hypochlorous acid into chloramine solution for use as a disinfecting agent.  The maximum quantity of chlorine and ammonia stored at Yuma Desalting Plant exceeds the federal RMP specified threshold quantities of 2,500 pounds and 10,000 pounds, respectively ; thus, the facility is subject to federal RMP regulations.  The anhydrous chlorine and ammonia processes are Program 3 processes.  

Summary of the Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps 

Yuma Desalting Plant is in compliance with federal Process Safety Management requirements. Yuma Desalting PlantA?s accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements:
Detailed management system and clear levels of responsibilities and team member roles.
Comprehensive process safety information that is readily available to staff, emergency responders, and contractors.
Comprehen

sive preventive maintenance program.
Performance of process hazard analysis of equipment and procedures with operation and maintenance staff participation and review.
Use of state-of-the-art process and safety equipment.
Use of accurate and effective operating procedures, written with the participation of the operators.
High level of training of the operators and maintenance staff.
Implementation of an incident investigation, inspection, and auditing program using qualified staff.

Chemical-specific prevention steps include availability of self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA), awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of chlorine and ammonia, and presence of chlorine detectors and alarms.

Process and Chemical Safety Information

Comprehensive chemical data have been assembled to include regulatory reporting and action thresholds, health hazard, and chemical exposure limitations, as well as detailed physical properties of chlorine and ammonia.  This information includes chlorine and ammonia background information and MSDS sheets.

Details such as maximum intended inventory and safe upper and lower operating limits are on file at the facility.  The Bureau of Reclamation also has procedures in place that is triggered to update process safety information if there is a major change that makes existing information inaccurate.

The chlorine and ammonia processes are equipped with a number of safety features designed to prevent accidental releases.  Such safety devices include chlorine leak detectors and alarms, pressure and level indication, and emergency eye-wash and shower.  

Process Hazard Analysis 

In 2006 and 2007, a detailed process hazard analysis (PHA) was conducted for the chlorine and ammonia systems, respectively.  The chlorine and ammonia PHAs were updated in November 2009.  The PHA will be updated within a five-year period or whenever there is major change in the processes.   A list of recommended actions was developed during the 2009 PHAs to imp

rove the chlorine and ammonia safety and staff is currently evaluating and implementing these recommendations, as appropriate.  Staff will document the completion of recommended actions.

Operating Procedures

The Bureau of Reclamation maintains written operating procedures that provide clear instructions for chlorine and ammonia processes. The operating procedures include start-up, normal operation, and shutdown procedures.  Operating procedures will be developed and put in place prior to any new process equipment coming on line or changes made in the handling of chlorine and ammonia equipment, and reconfiguration of the facilities.

Training 

Yuma Desalting Plant employees presently involved in operating or maintaining the chlorine and ammonia processes are trained in an overview of the processes and detailed applicable operating and maintenance procedures. The Bureau of Reclamation ensures that each employee newly assigned to the processes, is trained and tested to be competent in the operating procedures listed pertaining to their duties.  Yuma Desalting Plant training program includes as a minimum the following elements: (1) process safety information (2) process technology and process equipment, including safety systems, (3) maintenance procedures, and (4) operating procedures for the chlorine and ammonia system.

Each employee (presently involved in operating the chlorine and ammonia processes) has been trained to acquire the knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely carry out the duties and responsibilities, including emergency actions.  

Refresher training is provided annually to each employee operating the covered process to ensure that the employee understands and adheres to the current operating procedures.  In addition, the Bureau of Reclamation ensures that operators are trained in any updated or new procedures prior to startup of a process after a major change as indicated in their management of change procedures.

The Bureau of Reclamation prepare

s and retains records of initial and refresher training, provides certification of the records, which includes the identity of the employee, the date of training, and the signature of the person (s) administering the training.

Contractors

The Bureau of Reclamation has procedures and policies in place that ensure that only contractors with good safety programs are selected to perform work on and around the chlorine and ammonia processes and that the contractors are properly informed of the hazards, access limitations to these process areas, and emergency action procedures, and prepared to safely complete the work.  The Bureau of Reclamation holds contractor safety briefings before allowing them near or in the process areas; controls access to the process areas, and evaluates the contractorA?s performance.

Pre-Startup Safety Review and Mechanical Integrity Program

The Bureau of Reclamation  has procedures in place to ensure that a pre-startup safety review is conducted prior to starting a new covered process or prior to making modifications to the chlorine and ammonia systems that require a Management of Change procedure implementation.  These procedures ensure that no new/significantly modified process will start-up and no regulated substances will be introduced into such a process prior to the pre-startup safety review. 

The Bureau of Reclamation uses a manual system that assures inspection, testing, and maintenance of chlorine and ammonia equipment in accordance with the manufacturer and industry groups.

Hot Work Permits and Management of Change 

The Bureau of Reclamation requires employees and contractors to employ safe work practices when performing A?hot workA? in, on, or around the covered process.  The Bureau of Reclamation uses a permitting program to ensure hot work is conducted safely on or near a process involving chlorine and ammonia.

The Bureau of Reclamation provides a system and approach to maintain and implement any management of change or mod

ifications to equipment, procedures, chemicals, and processing conditions. This system allows Yuma Desalting Plant staff to identify and review safety hazards or provide additional safety, process, or chemical information to existing data before the proposed change would either compromise system safety or need training to be completed.

Internal Compliance Audits

Internal compliance audits will be conducted every 3 years to verify compliance with the programs and procedures contained in the RMP.  The Bureau of Reclamation assembles an audit team that will include personnel knowledgeable in the Risk Management Program rule and in the processes.  This team will evaluate whether the prevention program satisfies the requirements of the Risk Management Program rule and whether the prevention program is sufficient to help ensure safe operation of the processes.  The results of the audit will be documented, recommendations resolved, and appropriate enhancements to the prevention program will be implemented.

Incident Investigation

The Bureau of Reclamation investigates all incidents that could reasonably have resulted in a catastrophic release (serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment) so that similar accidents can be prevented.  An investigation team is assembled and the investigation is initiated within 48 hours of the incident.  The results of the investigation are documented, recommendations are resolved, and appropriate process enhancements are implemented.  Information found during the investigation is reviewed by affected staff and added or used to revise operating and maintenance procedures.

Five-Year Accident History Summary

EPA RMP regulations require reporting the five-year accident history of the covered processes.  The details of accidental releases are required for accidents that have caused at least one of the following:
Onsite deaths, injuries, or significant property damage
Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environment

al damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place

The Yuma Desalting Plant has had no accidents involving chlorine and ammonia.

Emergency Response Program Summary

The Bureau of Reclamation has established a written emergency action program that is followed by the employees to help safely control accidental releases of hazardous substances.  This program has been coordinated with the Yuma Rural/Metro Fire Department, which is a member of the Local Emergency Response Planning Committee (LEPC).  

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

A number of studies and inspections have been conducted to improve the safety of the chlorine and ammonia processes at the Yuma Desalting Plant including:
The process hazard analysis conducted in August 2006 and November 2009.
A review of the chlorine system in October 2006.


During these studies and inspections, several additional risk reduction measures were recommended to improve safety at Yuma Desalting Plant.  Details of the recommendations from the process hazard can be found in the prevention program document.  The risk reduction measures include confirming vendor procedures, confirming maintenance procedures, and evaluating the need to add safety equipment. The implementation of these recommendations will further improve the safety of the chlorine and ammonia systems.
